body:
Should Kafka itself taking care of bad clients ? 
I think that it's the infrastructure that should look after them.
As said, our production experience is that even when the number of new ssl connection is not great, i.e. not large enough to be blocked by the firewalling, they may impact significantly on the operation of the kafka cluster.

It is probably due to how expensive the SSL handshake is in Java. We have seen that a HAProxy machine doesn't even blink on the same rate of new SSL connections ...
cc @ijuma @hachikuji
@ijuma the Jenkins build failed to complete again. However all tests pass locally for me
Which Java implementation and version have you seen this with?

Hey @rajinisivaram, this LGTM for the specific problem. I think it would be worth adding a similar fix in `org.apache.kafka.common.metrics.JmxReporter`. Although we don't appear to include the hostname for metrics in `NetworkClient`, it seems like we probably should (I'll create a separate JIRA for this).

@enothereska @hjafarpour  Do you have a timeline for this fix? We need this fix as part of one of our client apps that we are building that uses spring cloud stream. Anything my team or I can do to help?

IBM JRE 1.7.0 with IBM's J9 VM 
using TLS 1.2
@ijuma Will you be able to review this?

I'm not really sure about this PR for 0.10.1, we have used the term "new producer" and "new consumer" quite a bit and it is perhaps a bit too early to remove that. Maybe we should merge this in trunk but leave 0.10.1 as is? My thinking is that in 0.10.1, `-new-consumer` is no longer needed and by next release, we have a good case for getting rid of the term. We would want to update the tool option documentation too, in that case.
Thanks for the PR. I'm wondering if it's enough to make this field `volatile`. What about `buffer`?
Also, while you're changing the producer, can you remove `Sender.clientId`, which seems unused?

@ijuma It makes sense that we hold on to the terms 'new consumer' and 'old consumer' a bit longer. How about updating the quick start examples to use the new consumer (which is part of this PR)? Should I open a separate minor PR to update those examples for 0.10.1?

Seems like we could drop the "new" terminology for the producer at least. It's hardly new anymore and we don't even support the old one. As long as we continue supporting both consumers, however, the "new" word is useful to distinguish which one users should be using.

@hachikuji the old producers are still supported, they've just been deprecated (which only means that they will be removed in a future major release and that they won't be gaining new features).

@vahidhashemian updating the quick start examples sounds great. Also, the remaining "beta" note for the new consumer that I missed last time around should be fixed.
After looking at it a bit more, I think `buffer` should be `volatile` as well.

@ijuma Fair enough. Looking through the documentation, we're not consistent on the usage. In most places, it's just "the producer," or even "the Java producer." I doubt anyone would care if we dropped the word "new" from the other mentions, but no strong preference here.
Also, can we add a comment on both of these variables explaining that they are used by both `sender` and `user` threads while the other variables are only used by the `user` thread?
if we're not consistent already, then fair enough.
Thanks for the PR! Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 with a minor tweak.

The reason for the system test failure on `ThrottlingTest` is the following:

```
Exception in thread "main" org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: Failed to construct kafka producer
        at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.KafkaProducer.<init>(KafkaProducer.java:339)
        at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.KafkaProducer.<init>(KafkaProducer.java:189)
        at org.apache.kafka.tools.ProducerPerformance.main(ProducerPerformance.java:68)
Caused by: org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /mnt/security/test.keystore.jks (No such file or directory)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.network.SslChannelBuilder.configure(SslChannelBuilder.java:44)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.network.ChannelBuilders.create(ChannelBuilders.java:70)
        at org.apache.kafka.clients.ClientUtils.createChannelBuilder(ClientUtils.java:85)
        at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.KafkaProducer.<init>(KafkaProducer.java:303)
        ... 2 more
Caused by: org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /mnt/security/test.keystore.jks (No such file or directory)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.security.ssl.SslFactory.configure(SslFactory.java:121)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.network.SslChannelBuilder.configure(SslChannelBuilder.java:41)
        ... 5 more
Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /mnt/security/test.keystore.jks (No such file or directory)
        at java.io.FileInputStream.open(Native Method)
        at java.io.FileInputStream.<init>(FileInputStream.java:146)
        at java.io.FileInputStream.<init>(FileInputStream.java:101)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.security.ssl.SslFactory$SecurityStore.load(SslFactory.java:216)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.security.ssl.SslFactory$SecurityStore.access$000(SslFactory.java:201)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.security.ssl.SslFactory.createSSLContext(SslFactory.java:137)
        at org.apache.kafka.common.security.ssl.SslFactory.configure(SslFactory.java:119)
        ... 6 more
```

An SSL error even though the tests don't use ssl. This is not reproducible on a non-jenkins system test setup : the tests pass fine.

@ijuma @hachikuji Updated the PR as advised. Also dropped 'new' from producer mentions as per latest comments.

On a separate note, I've been wondering if there is anyway to stop outdated PR builds on Jenkins? Sometimes I push a few updates in a short timeframe and it would be helpful to stop the old builds to free up Jenkins resources. Thanks.
@dguy I agree throwing an `InvalidStateStoreException` to indicate users to re-discover is better.

@ijuma Yes, buffer should be volatile as well. I feel it is a little too much to explain the external usage of the variables. I added comments saying that those variables may be read and written by different threads so we need to make them volatile.
@guozhang I pushed that change already

Looking at this even more, it seems like there are other issues.

In the case where we call `close` from the `Sender` thread (which used to be the only behaviour before but now only happens some of the time), we call `compressor.close()`, which invokes `bufferStream.buffer()`. But the buffer returned there is in a non-volatile variable that gets updated when the buffer needs to be expanded while writing data from the user thread. Seems like that `buffer` also needs to be volatile.

Seems like the concurrency strategy for the new producer hasn't really been thought through.

@jjkoshy adding the callback timeout seems nice and makes it more clear. On the other hand can we have a single timeout which kafka internally splits up in to these 3 and we can also factor in retires? In that way user has to provide a single timeout and the request can block during the initial phase or get back the results with in that time period. I understand having a single timeout might not be possible, but IMO it would be good to give it a thought since we are planning to add one more timeout config.
@dguy @enothereska Unit test fixed.

@dguy I think this is indeed an issue but setting the dummy timestamp to `system time` may not be the perfect solution, since remember that these timestamps will be the timestamp of the message used for log rolling / retention / etc.

So suppose you are processing data from 24 hours ago this changelog message will cause the log segment to be garbage collected immediately.

A different option would be to modify the `restoration` process of the state store to allow users to have a warm state store before replaying the changelog, this is equivalent to writing some data that are not based on any incoming records when initializing the store. More specifically:
1. If the local state store exist, replay from checkpointed offset to tail.
2. If there is no state store, apply user's specified restoration logic so that the store is warm-constructed and reply from beginning offset to tail.

What do you think? @dguy @mjsax
Becket pointed out in the JIRA that we synchronize on the same `deque` before calling `tryAppend` or `close`, so we don't need any of the volatiles in this PR.
LGTM. Given the current state of MM tests and the size of this fix, I'd be OK opening a separate JIRA to follow up with more testing later.
Sounds good to me.
@guozhangwang @enothereska This patch reduced test runtime by about 50%. It's a general test improvement. Hope it does also fix the timeout issue with `ResetIntegrationTest`
I once did this change but reviewers mentioned that this is not a good pattern since we may still want to check after exiting the while loop if the condition is still met. cc @ijuma and @hachikuji
IMHO, there is nothing else to do, to improve `ResetIntegrationTest` (besides of increasing the timeout...)
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1. @becketqin Would you mind creating a follow-up JIRA for the MM tests?
What do you mean by "reduced test runtime by about 50%"? Are you saying that it halved the time taken to run the streams test suite?
@hachikuji will do.
Thanks to @ijuma's efforts, I was able to successfully run this on Jenkins: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/576/
Not sure for the whole test suite. But for `ResetIntegationTest` and for newly `JoinIntegrationTest` (https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1777)

@MayureshGharat I may have misunderstood, but exposing a single timeout and splitting internally sounds like it would make matters much worse. In fact the suggestion above was to add an additional timeout to fix the issue that we are overloading one timeout for both the request timeout and the time spent in the accumulator.
@vahidhashemian Left a minor comment on the recent commit. The rest LGTM.
Merged to trunk and 0.10.1. Thanks for the patch!
@junrao @ijuma @becketqin Thanks for the reviews! The patch was updated and I posted some performance results. Let me know if you'd like to see some more analysis or if you have any other concerns.

Anyof @guozhangwang @dguy @enothereska @miguno @hjafarpour

After a `cleanup()` we need to re-create `state.dir`, otherwise, we might run into an exception if `cleanup()` is called **after** the second `KafkaStreams` instance got created (see modified test of this PR)

Exception would be

```
Exception in thread "StreamThread-2" org.apache.kafka.streams.errors.StreamsException: stream-thread [StreamThread-2] Failed to rebalance
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread.runLoop(StreamThread.java:339)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread.run(StreamThread.java:235)
Caused by: org.apache.kafka.streams.errors.ProcessorStateException: Error while creating the state manager
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.AbstractTask.<init>(AbstractTask.java:69)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamTask.<init>(StreamTask.java:87)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread.createStreamTask(StreamThread.java:566)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread.addStreamTasks(StreamThread.java:593)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread.access$000(StreamThread.java:69)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread$1.onPartitionsAssigned(StreamThread.java:120)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerCoordinator.onJoinComplete(ConsumerCoordinator.java:225)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.AbstractCoordinator.joinGroupIfNeeded(AbstractCoordinator.java:321)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.AbstractCoordinator.ensureActiveGroup(AbstractCoordinator.java:273)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerCoordinator.poll(ConsumerCoordinator.java:256)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.KafkaConsumer.pollOnce(KafkaConsumer.java:1003)
    at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.KafkaConsumer.poll(KafkaConsumer.java:969)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThread.runLoop(StreamThread.java:335)
    ... 1 more
Caused by: java.nio.file.NoSuchFileException: /tmp/kafka-streams/application-reset-integration-test/0_0/.lock
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixException.translateToIOException(UnixException.java:86)
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixException.rethrowAsIOException(UnixException.java:102)
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixException.rethrowAsIOException(UnixException.java:107)
    at sun.nio.fs.UnixFileSystemProvider.newFileChannel(UnixFileSystemProvider.java:177)
    at java.nio.channels.FileChannel.open(FileChannel.java:287)
    at java.nio.channels.FileChannel.open(FileChannel.java:335)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StateDirectory.getOrCreateFileChannel(StateDirectory.java:172)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StateDirectory.lock(StateDirectory.java:86)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.ProcessorStateManager.<init>(ProcessorStateManager.java:95)
    at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.AbstractTask.<init>(AbstractTask.java:66)
    ... 13 more
```
LGTM.
LGTM, I won't merge to give @guozhangwang a chance to take a look.
@guozhangwang can you review this?
@hachikuji  let me ping you again...

@apurvam, the system tests passed. :) Unfortunately, the branch has some conflicts. Can you please resolve them and then just run your tests in the branch builder? I also left a couple of minor comments that I missed last time.
@hachikuji LGTM, but I'll wait for Jun to take a look at the test results and confirm that he's happy with them.

@hachikuji Thanks for the results. It looks good. Also, it seems that the change we made in the patch would be more sensitive to the request rate and the keys per request because that may impact the size of the operations queue. I increased the rate to 10000, fixed the request size at 1000, and only changed keys per request to 10 and 100. And here are the results.

Test off the trunk

| Keys per request | elapsed time ms | target rate | actual rate | process cpu time ms | G1 Old Generation count | G1 Young Generation count | G1 Old Generation time ms | G1 Young Generation time ms |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 10 | 100681 | 9942.235611 | 9942.235611 | 17770 | 0 | 22 | 0 | 102 |
| 100 | 100181 | 9991.906556 | 9991.906556 | 46760 | 0 | 49 | 0 | 261 |

Test with the patch

| Keys per request | elapsed time ms | target rate | actual rate | process cpu time ms | G1 Old Generation count | G1 Young Generation count | G1 Old Generation time ms | G1 Young Generation time ms |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 10 | 99810 | 10029.08435 | 10029.08435 | 19420 | 0 | 34 | 0 | 125 |
| 100 | 99880 | 10022.04851 | 10022.04851 | 55620 | 0 | 166 | 0 | 537 |

It looks GC and CPU time is a little higher with the patch (which is expected due to memory copy), but it seems not that bad. I also tested 50pct latency of 10 ms and 75pct latency of 20 ms (the approximate number we see in real system) and the result did not vary much. Given that in reality we rarely see the request rate reaching 10000, I think it is probably fine. Let's see what @junrao and @ijuma say.

By the way, one final item that is worth considering is that a `Vector` is less memory efficient than `LinkedList` or `List` if the number of elements is small. Have a look at its fields:

``` scala
    private[immutable] var depth: Int = _
    private[immutable] var display0: Array[AnyRef] = _
    private[immutable] var display1: Array[AnyRef] = _
    private[immutable] var display2: Array[AnyRef] = _
    private[immutable] var display3: Array[AnyRef] = _
    private[immutable] var display4: Array[AnyRef] = _
    private[immutable] var display5: Array[AnyRef] = _
```

For small collections, one would expect most of the fields to be empty, but you still have the space required for the 6 references. This is the main reason why `scala.List` is still the default immutable collection type in Scala (as `Vector` is a better general purpose collection otherwise).

I mention this because Jun said that the watch list per key would be small. Would the number of keys be very large making the memory efficiency of the watch list per key important?
I wrote my comment in parallel with Becket's comment. Worth pointing out that the case with 100 keys per request doubles the G1 Young Generation time.
LGTM, @hachikuji or @junrao, either of you wants to take a look at this simple fix?
Merging to trunk and 0.10.1 as @guozhangwang has reviewed it and his only minor comment was addressed by @dguy.
build timed out. tests pass locally for me.

LGTM

@dguy I can revert all formatting changes -- however, I am wondering if anyone would do a "reformat only" PR? I guess if we want to get unique auto-formatted code, we need to do this gradually over all PRs. WDYT?
LGTM

Nice catch. But simply delete-and-recreate may still be vulnerable to race conditions when two instances are bootstrapping concurrently, since the file lock is only on the task level while deleting is on the global application level?

Yes, i'm not sure anyone would do a reformat only PR. However, i think the best approach is as you suggested, do it gradually, i.e., just changes in the area you are currently working in. Otherwise it becomes to much noise to process, i.e., hence the struggle to review the real changes
Yeah I agree. How about this: let me ask the users who asked for this feature their concrete use case and see if that can be resolved in other ways first.
LGTM besides @enothereska 's comment, the parameter is in ms not seconds.
